column2: But when a young lady is to be a heroine, the perverseness of forty surrounding families cannot prevent her.
column3: But when a young lady is to be a heroine, the perverseness of forty surrounding families cannot prevent her.

column2: Something must and will happen to throw a hero in her way.
column3: Something must and will happen to throw a hero in her way.

column2: Mr. Allen, who owned the chief of the property about Fullerton, the village in Wiltshire where the Morlands lived, was ordered to Bath for the benefit of a gouty constitution--and his lady, a good-humoured woman, fond of Miss Morland, and probably aware that if adventures will not befall a young lady in her own village, she must seek them abroad, invited her to go with them.
column3: mr Allen, who owned the chief of the property about Fullerton, the village in Wiltshire where the Morlands lived, was ordered to Bath for the benefit of a gouty constitution-and his lady, a good humoured woman, fond of Miss Morland, and probably aware that if adventures will not befall a young lady in her own village, she must seek them abroad, invited her to go with them.

column2: Mr. and Mrs. Morland were all compliance, and Catherine all happiness.
column3: mr and mrs Morland were all compliance, and Catherine all happiness.

column2: CHAPTER 2
column3: CHAPTER two

column2: In addition to what has been already said of Catherine Morland's personal and mental endowments, when about to be launched into all the difficulties and dangers of a six weeks' residence in Bath, it may be stated, for the reader's more certain information, lest the following pages should otherwise fail of giving any idea of what her character is meant to be, that her heart was affectionate; her disposition cheerful and open, without conceit or affectation of any kind--her manners just removed from the awkwardness and shyness of a girl; her person pleasing, and, when in good looks, pretty--and her mind about as ignorant and uninformed as the female mind at seventeen usually is.
column3: In addition to what has been already said of Catherine Morland's personal and mental endowments, when about to be launched into all the difficulties and dangers of a six weeks' residence in Bath, it may be stated, for the reader's more certain information, lest the following pages should otherwise fail of giving any idea of what her character is meant to be, that her heart was affectionate; her disposition cheerful and open, without conceit or affectation of any kind-her manners just removed from the awkwardness and shyness of a girl; her person pleasing, and, when in good looks, pretty-and her mind about as ignorant and uninformed as the female mind at seventeen usually is.

column2: When the hour of departure drew near, the maternal anxiety of Mrs. Morland will be naturally supposed to be most severe.
column3: When the hour of departure drew near, the maternal anxiety of mrs Morland will be naturally supposed to be most severe.

column2: A thousand alarming presentiments of evil to her beloved Catherine from this terrific separation must oppress her heart with sadness, and drown her in tears for the last day or two of their being together; and advice of the most important and applicable nature must of course flow from her wise lips in their parting conference in her closet.
column3: A thousand alarming presentiments of evil to her beloved Catherine from this terrific separation must oppress her heart with sadness, and drown her in tears for the last day or two of their being together; and advice of the most important and applicable nature must of course flow from her wise lips in their parting conference in her closet.

column2: Cautions against the violence of such noblemen and baronets as delight in forcing young ladies away to some remote farm-house, must, at such a moment, relieve the fulness of her heart.
column3: Cautions against the violence of such noblemen and baronets as delight in forcing young ladies away to some remote farm house, must, at such a moment, relieve the fulness of her heart.

column2: Who would not think so?
column3: Who would not think so?

column2: But Mrs. Morland knew so little of lords and baronets, that she entertained no notion of their general mischievousness, and was wholly unsuspicious of danger to her daughter from their machinations.
column3: But mrs Morland knew so little of lords and baronets, that she entertained no notion of their general mischievousness, and was wholly unsuspicious of danger to her daughter from their machinations.

column2: Her cautions were confined to the following points.
column3: Her cautions were confined to the following points.

column2: I beg, Catherine, you will always wrap yourself up very warm about the throat, when you come from the rooms at night; and I wish you would try to keep some account of the money you spend; I will give you this little book on purpose.
column3: I beg, Catherine, you will always wrap yourself up very warm about the throat, when you come from the rooms at night; and I wish you would try to keep some account of the money you spend; I will give you this little book on purpose.

column2: Sally, or rather Sarah (for what young lady of common gentility will reach the age of sixteen without altering her name as far as she can?), must from situation be at this time the intimate friend and confidante of her sister.
column3: Sally, or rather Sarah (for what young lady of common gentility will reach the age of sixteen without altering her name as far as she can?), must from situation be at this time the intimate friend and confidante of her sister.

column2: It is remarkable, however, that she neither insisted on Catherine's writing by every post, nor exacted her promise of transmitting the character of every new acquaintance, nor a detail of every interesting conversation that Bath might produce.
column3: It is remarkable, however, that she neither insisted on Catherine's writing by every post, nor exacted her promise of transmitting the character of every new acquaintance, nor a detail of every interesting conversation that Bath might produce.

column2: Everything indeed relative to this important journey was done, on the part of the Morlands, with a degree of moderation and composure, which seemed rather consistent with the common feelings of common life, than with the refined susceptibilities, the tender emotions which the first separation of a heroine from her family ought always to excite.
column3: Everything indeed relative to this important journey was done, on the part of the Morlands, with a degree of moderation and composure, which seemed rather consistent with the common feelings of common life, than with the refined susceptibilities, the tender emotions which the first separation of a heroine from her family ought always to excite.

column2: Her father, instead of giving her an unlimited order on his banker, or even putting an hundred pounds bank-bill into her hands, gave her only ten guineas, and promised her more when she wanted it.
column3: Her father, instead of giving her an unlimited order on his banker, or even putting an hundred pounds bank bill into her hands, gave her only ten guineas, and promised her more when she wanted it.

column2: Under these unpromising auspices, the parting took place, and the journey began.
column3: Under these unpromising auspices, the parting took place, and the journey began.

column2: It was performed with suitable quietness and uneventful safety.
column3: It was performed with suitable quietness and uneventful safety.

column2: Neither robbers nor tempests befriended them, nor one lucky overturn to introduce them to the hero.
column3: Neither robbers nor tempests befriended them, nor one lucky overturn to introduce them to the hero.

column2: Nothing more alarming occurred than a fear, on Mrs. Allen's side, of having once left her clogs behind her at an inn, and that fortunately proved to be groundless.
column3: Nothing more alarming occurred than a fear, on mrs Allen's side, of having once left her clogs behind her at an inn, and that fortunately proved to be groundless.

column2: They arrived at Bath.
column3: They arrived at Bath.

column2: Catherine was all eager delight--her eyes were here, there, everywhere, as they approached its fine and striking environs, and afterwards drove through those streets which conducted them to the hotel.
column3: Catherine was all eager delight-her eyes were here, there, everywhere, as they approached its fine and striking environs, and afterwards drove through those streets which conducted them to the hotel.

column2: She was come to be happy, and she felt happy already.
column3: She was come to be happy, and she felt happy already.

column2: They were soon settled in comfortable lodgings in Pulteney Street.
column3: They were soon settled in comfortable lodgings in Pulteney Street.

column2: It is now expedient to give some description of Mrs. Allen, that the reader may be able to judge in what manner her actions will hereafter tend to promote the general distress of the work, and how she will, probably, contribute to reduce poor Catherine to all the desperate wretchedness of which a last volume is capable--whether by her imprudence, vulgarity, or jealousy--whether by intercepting her letters, ruining her character, or turning her out of doors.
column3: It is now expedient to give some description of mrs Allen, that the reader may be able to judge in what manner her actions will hereafter tend to promote the general distress of the work, and how she will, probably, contribute to reduce poor Catherine to all the desperate wretchedness of which a last volume is capable-whether by her imprudence, vulgarity, or jealousy-whether by intercepting her letters, ruining her character, or turning her out of doors.

column2: Mrs. Allen was one of that numerous class of females, whose society can raise no other emotion than surprise at there being any men in the world who could like them well enough to marry them.
column3: mrs Allen was one of that numerous class of females, whose society can raise no other emotion than surprise at there being any men in the world who could like them well enough to marry them.

column2: She had neither beauty, genius, accomplishment, nor manner.
column3: She had neither beauty, genius, accomplishment, nor manner.

column2: The air of a gentlewoman, a great deal of quiet, inactive good temper, and a trifling turn of mind were all that could account for her being the choice of a sensible, intelligent man like Mr. Allen.
column3: The air of a gentlewoman, a great deal of quiet, inactive good temper, and a trifling turn of mind were all that could account for her being the choice of a sensible, intelligent man like mr Allen.

column2: In one respect she was admirably fitted to introduce a young lady into public, being as fond of going everywhere and seeing everything herself as any young lady could be.
column3: In one respect she was admirably fitted to introduce a young lady into public, being as fond of going everywhere and seeing everything herself as any young lady could be.

column2: Dress was her passion.
column3: Dress was her passion.

column2: She had a most harmless delight in being fine; and our heroine's entree into life could not take place till after three or four days had been spent in learning what was mostly worn, and her chaperone was provided with a dress of the newest fashion.
column3: She had a most harmless delight in being fine; and our heroine's entree into life could not take place till after three or four days had been spent in learning what was mostly worn, and her chaperone was provided with a dress of the newest fashion.

column2: Catherine too made some purchases herself, and when all these matters were arranged, the important evening came which was to usher her into the Upper Rooms.
column3: Catherine too made some purchases herself, and when all these matters were arranged, the important evening came which was to usher her into the Upper Rooms.

column2: Her hair was cut and dressed by the best hand, her clothes put on with care, and both Mrs. Allen and her maid declared she looked quite as she should do.
column3: Her hair was cut and dressed by the best hand, her clothes put on with care, and both mrs Allen and her maid declared she looked quite as she should do.

column2: With such encouragement, Catherine hoped at least to pass uncensured through the crowd.
column3: With such encouragement, Catherine hoped at least to pass uncensured through the crowd.

column2: As for admiration, it was always very welcome when it came, but she did not depend on it.
column3: As for admiration, it was always very welcome when it came, but she did not depend on it.

column2: Mrs. Allen was so long in dressing that they did not enter the ballroom till late.
column3: mrs Allen was so long in dressing that they did not enter the ballroom till late.

column2: The season was full, the room crowded, and the two ladies squeezed in as well as they could.
column3: The season was full, the room crowded, and the two ladies squeezed in as well as they could.

column2: As for Mr. Allen, he repaired directly to the card-room, and left them to enjoy a mob by themselves. With more care for the safety of her new gown than for the comfort of her protegee, Mrs. Allen made her way through the throng of men by the door, as swiftly as the necessary caution would allow; Catherine, however, kept close at her side, and linked her arm too firmly within her friend's to be torn asunder by any common effort of a struggling assembly.
column3: As for mr Allen, he repaired directly to the card room, and left them to enjoy a mob by themselves. With more care for the safety of her new gown than for the comfort of her protegee, mrs Allen made her way through the throng of men by the door, as swiftly as the necessary caution would allow; Catherine, however, kept close at her side, and linked her arm too firmly within her friend's to be torn asunder by any common effort of a struggling assembly.

column2: But to her utter amazement she found that to proceed along the room was by no means the way to disengage themselves from the crowd; it seemed rather to increase as they went on, whereas she had imagined that when once fairly within the door, they should easily find seats and be able to watch the dances with perfect convenience.
column3: But to her utter amazement she found that to proceed along the room was by no means the way to disengage themselves from the crowd; it seemed rather to increase as they went on, whereas she had imagined that when once fairly within the door, they should easily find seats and be able to watch the dances with perfect convenience.

column2: But this was far from being the case, and though by unwearied diligence they gained even the top of the room, their situation was just the same; they saw nothing of the dancers but the high feathers of some of the ladies.
column3: But this was far from being the case, and though by unwearied diligence they gained even the top of the room, their situation was just the same; they saw nothing of the dancers but the high feathers of some of the ladies.

column2: Still they moved on--something better was yet in view; and by a continued exertion of strength and ingenuity they found themselves at last in the passage behind the highest bench.
column3: Still they moved on-something better was yet in view; and by a continued exertion of strength and ingenuity they found themselves at last in the passage behind the highest bench.

column2: Here there was something less of crowd than below; and hence Miss Morland had a comprehensive view of all the company beneath her, and of all the dangers of her late passage through them.
column3: Here there was something less of crowd than below; and hence Miss Morland had a comprehensive view of all the company beneath her, and of all the dangers of her late passage through them.

column2: It was a splendid sight, and she began, for the first time that evening, to feel herself at a ball: she longed to dance, but she had not an acquaintance in the room.
column3: It was a splendid sight, and she began, for the first time that evening, to feel herself at a ball: she longed to dance, but she had not an acquaintance in the room.

column2: Mrs. Allen did all that she could do in such a case by saying very placidly, every now and then, "I wish you could dance, my dear--I wish you could get a partner." For some time her young friend felt obliged to her for these wishes; but they were repeated so often, and proved so totally ineffectual, that Catherine grew tired at last, and would thank her no more.
column3: mrs Allen did all that she could do in such a case by saying very placidly, every now and then, "I wish you could dance, my dear-I wish you could get a partner." column2: They were not long able, however, to enjoy the repose of the eminence they had so laboriously gained.
column3: They were not long able, however, to enjoy the repose of the eminence they had so laboriously gained.

column2: Everybody was shortly in motion for tea, and they must squeeze out like the rest.
column3: Everybody was shortly in motion for tea, and they must squeeze out like the rest.

column2: Catherine began to feel something of disappointment--she was tired of being continually pressed against by people, the generality of whose faces possessed nothing to interest, and with all of whom she was so wholly unacquainted that she could not relieve the irksomeness of imprisonment by the exchange of a syllable with any of her fellow captives; and when at last arrived in the tea-room, she felt yet more the awkwardness of having no party to join, no acquaintance to claim, no gentleman to assist them.
column3: Catherine began to feel something of disappointment-she was tired of being continually pressed against by people, the generality of whose faces possessed nothing to interest, and with all of whom she was so wholly unacquainted that she could not relieve the irksomeness of imprisonment by the exchange of a syllable with any of her fellow captives; and when at last arrived in the tea room, she felt yet more the awkwardness of having no party to join, no acquaintance to claim, no gentleman to assist them.

column2: They saw nothing of Mr. Allen; and after looking about them in vain for a more eligible situation, were obliged to sit down at the end of a table, at which a large party were already placed, without having anything to do there, or anybody to speak to, except each other.
column3: They saw nothing of mr Allen; and after looking about them in vain for a more eligible situation, were obliged to sit down at the end of a table, at which a large party were already placed, without having anything to do there, or anybody to speak to, except each other.

column2: Mrs. Allen congratulated herself, as soon as they were seated, on having preserved her gown from injury.
column3: mrs Allen congratulated herself, as soon as they were seated, on having preserved her gown from injury.

column2: It would have been very shocking to have it torn, said she, "would not it?
column3: It would have been very shocking to have it torn, said she, "would not it?

column2: It is such a delicate muslin. For my part I have not seen anything I like so well in the whole room, I assure you."
column3: It is such a delicate muslin. For my part one have not seen anything I like so well in the whole room, I assure you."

column2: How uncomfortable it is, whispered Catherine, "not to have a single acquaintance here!"
column3: How uncomfortable it is, whispered Catherine, "not to have a single acquaintance here!"

column2: Yes, my dear, replied Mrs. Allen, with perfect serenity, "it is very uncomfortable indeed."
column3: Yes, my dear, replied mrs Allen, with perfect serenity, "it is very uncomfortable indeed."

column2: What shall we do?	What shall we do?

column2: The gentlemen and ladies at this table look as if they wondered why we came here--we seem forcing ourselves into their party."
column3: The gentlemen and ladies at this table look as if they wondered why we came here-we seem forcing ourselves into their party."

column2: Aye, so we do.	Aye, so we do.

column2: That is very disagreeable.
column3: That is very disagreeable.

column2: I wish we had a large acquaintance here."
column3: I wish we had a large acquaintance here."

column2: I wish we had any--it would be somebody to go to.
column3: I wish we had any-it would be somebody to go to.

column2: Very true, my dear; and if we knew anybody we would join them directly. The Skinners were here last year--I wish they were here now.
column3: Very true, my dear; and if we knew anybody we would join them directly. The Skinners were here last year-I wish they were here now.

column2: Had not we better go away as it is?	Had not we better go away as it is?

column2: Here are no tea-things for us, you see."
column3: Here are no tea things for us, you see."

column2: No more there are, indeed.	No more there are, indeed.

column2: How very provoking!
column3: How very provoking!

column2: But I think we had better sit still, for one gets so tumbled in such a crowd!
column3: But I think we had better sit still, for one gets so tumbled in such a crowd!

column2: How is my head, my dear?
column3: How is my head, my dear?

column2: Somebody gave me a push that has hurt it, I am afraid."
column3: Somebody gave me a push that has hurt it, I am afraid."

column2: No, indeed, it looks very nice.	No, indeed, it looks very nice.

column2: But, dear Mrs. Allen, are you sure there is nobody you know in all this multitude of people?
column3: But, dear mrs Allen, are you sure there is nobody you know in all this multitude of people?

column2: I think you must know somebody."
column3: I think you must know somebody."

column2: I don't, upon my word--I wish I did.	I don't, upon my word-I wish I did.

column2: I wish I had a large acquaintance here with all my heart, and then I should get you a partner.
column3: I wish I had a large acquaintance here with all my heart, and then I should get you a partner.

column2: I should be so glad to have you dance.
column3: I should be so glad to have you dance.

column2: There goes a strange-looking woman!
column3: There goes a strange looking woman!

column2: What an odd gown she has got on!
column3: What an odd gown she has got on!

column2: How old-fashioned it is!
column3: How old-fashioned it is!

column2: Look at the back."
column3: Look at the back."

column2: After some time they received an offer of tea from one of their neighbours; it was thankfully accepted, and this introduced a light conversation with the gentleman who offered it, which was the only time that anybody spoke to them during the evening, till they were discovered and joined by Mr. Allen when the dance was over.
column3: After some time they received an offer of tea from one of their neighbours; it was thankfully accepted, and this introduced a light conversation with the gentleman who offered it, which was the only time that anybody spoke to them during the evening, till they were discovered and joined by mr Allen when the dance was over.

column2: Well, Miss Morland, said he, directly, "I hope you have had an agreeable ball."
column3: Well, Miss Morland, said he, directly, "I hope you have had an agreeable ball."

column2: Very agreeable indeed, she replied, vainly endeavouring to hide a great yawn.
column3: Very agreeable indeed, she replied, vainly endeavouring to hide a great yawn.

column2: I wish she had been able to dance, said his wife; "I wish we could have got a partner for her.
column3: I wish she had been able to dance, said his wife; "I wish we could have got a partner for her.

column2: I have been saying how glad I should be if the Skinners were here this winter instead of last; or if the Parrys had come, as they talked of once, she might have danced with George Parry.
column3: I have been saying how glad I should be if the Skinners were here this winter instead of last; or if the Parrys had come, as they talked of once, she might have danced with George Parry.

column2: I am so sorry she has not had a partner!"
column3: I am so sorry she has not had a partner!"

column2: We shall do better another evening I hope, was Mr. Allen's consolation.
column3: We shall do better another evening I hope, was mr Allen's consolation.

column2: The company began to disperse when the dancing was over--enough to leave space for the remainder to walk about in some comfort; and now was the time for a heroine, who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening, to be noticed and admired.
column3: The company began to disperse when the dancing was over-enough to leave space for the remainder to walk about in some comfort; and now was the time for a heroine, who had not yet played a very distinguished part in the events of the evening, to be noticed and admired.

column2: Every five minutes, by removing some of the crowd, gave greater openings for her charms.
column3: Every five minutes, by removing some of the crowd, gave greater openings for her charms.

column2: She was now seen by many young men who had not been near her before.
column3: She was now seen by many young men who had not been near her before.

column2: Not one, however, started with rapturous wonder on beholding her, no whisper of eager inquiry ran round the room, nor was she once called a divinity by anybody.
column3: Not one, however, started with rapturous wonder on beholding her, no whisper of eager inquiry ran round the room, nor was she once called a divinity by anybody.

column2: Yet Catherine was in very good looks, and had the company only seen her three years before, they would now have thought her exceedingly handsome.
column3: Yet Catherine was in very good looks, and had the company only seen her three years before, they would now have thought her exceedingly handsome.

column2: She was looked at, however, and with some admiration; for, in her own hearing, two gentlemen pronounced her to be a pretty girl.
column3: She was looked at, however, and with some admiration; for, in her own hearing, two gentlemen pronounced her to be a pretty girl.

column2: Such words had their due effect; she immediately thought the evening pleasanter than she had found it before--her humble vanity was contented--she felt more obliged to the two young men for this simple praise than a true-quality heroine would have been for fifteen sonnets in celebration of her charms, and went to her chair in good humour with everybody, and perfectly satisfied with her share of public attention.
column3: Such words had their due effect; she immediately thought the evening pleasanter than she had found it before-her humble vanity was contented-she felt more obliged to the two young men for this simple praise than a true quality heroine would have been for fifteen sonnets in celebration of her charms, and went to her chair in good humour with everybody, and perfectly satisfied with her share of public attention.
